reviewText:
TIE Fighter is one of the best games that's ever been made, but a few bone-headed decisions that went into the Steam Port make it nigh unplayable. If you have a joystick, then by all means: buy it! Otherwise... well, see below.

If you buy the game you get two separate games installed onto your computer: the Classic Version and the Collector's Edition- which has voice acting and immeasurably better graphics. The Collector's Edition will not even run unless the game detects that a joystick is connected to your computer- I don't know if it will register a USB controller as a joystick or not. The Classic version- meanwhile- runs on a hideously glitchy version of DOS Box. I played for twenty minutes before 95% of the keys on my keyboard stopped working. I had to Ctrl-Alt-Del out of the game because the Abort Mission button wasn't working. Playing the classic edition I don't believe you can adjust the mouse sensitivity and you turn so friggin' slowly using the mouse that any kind of hectic mission is unplayable.

On the bright side: if you can actually play it, this game is one of the greatest flight sims ever made. Plenty of missions, an immersive story, energy management and targetting computer systems that keep the gameplay ever-changing, and a great variety of missions. Too bad the port is so ♥♥♥♥ed up.

reviewText:
Greatest Star Wars game ever made. Trust me, I've played nearly all of them. I've played the good ones (Jedi Knight/Dark Forces, Knights of the Old Republic), I've played the bad ones (Rebel Assault, Super Bombad Racing), and I've played the ones no one has ever heard of (The Gungan Frontier, Droidworks). TIE Fighter stands alone as the greatest Star Wars game ever made, and one of the great classic old-school PC games.

Star Wars: TIE Fighter is a flight simulator game. Remember when that used to be a genre? Where have all of those games gone? So if you're looking to play this game, you need to fight a USB joystick. Remember when those used to be a thing? Ahh the 90s... But seriously, get yourself a fight stick. This game DOES NOT play well with a mouse or keyboard. I haven't tried using a controller, but for the optimal TIE Fighter pilot experience, you're probably going to want a joystick.

Star Wars: TIE Fighter is a sort-of sequel to Star Wars: X-Wing, which was released a year earlier in 1993. I say sort-of" sequel because it's essentially the same game
date: but you play as the Empire instead of the Rebellion
hoursPlayed: way cooler. Star Wars fans know what I'm talking about. There's also a few game engine upgrades
voteText: mechanical tweaks and graphical enhancements in TIE Fighter which make it slightly more polished than its predecessor. You'll start as a lowly trainee pilot
helpfulPercent: given the Imperial standard TIE Fighter at the beginning of the first campaign. The first levels start you off doing routine cargo inspections and escort missions while teaching you the controls for the ship
votesHelpful: which are surprisingly complex. Nearly every button on the keyboard is mapped to one ship function or another. As you progress through the campaigns
votesTotal: you gain access to additional ships
column16: to TIE Bomber to eventually experimental prototype craft like the TIE Advanced. The mission types vary as well
column17: from cover missions to bombing raids
column19: even full on epic assaults as in the movies.\n\nWhile piloting your craft
column20: you'll usually need to pay attention to several systems at once. You need to watch the recharge rate of your lasers/ions. If there's not enough energy in the cannon bays
column21: you won't be able to fire. Increasing the recharge rate of your cannons draws power from other systems on the craft
column22: like shields or engines. You'll also need to watch the energy level of the shields. If there's not enough energy in the shields
column23: you're defenseless. But increasing the recharge rate of the shields similarly draws power from other systems like engines and cannons. So there's a little power balance subgame you'll be constantly playing throughout the mission which usually gets pretty frantic while your trying to keep one enemy ship in your sights while two or three others are on your tail. Some of the power balance is situational as well. For instance
column24: cannons are not as important when attacking a stationary defense platform with no starfighter support
column25: so cannon power can be redirected to engines or to boost shields. And shields are not as important as the speed to keep up and maneuver with faster targets
column27: shield power should be redirected to engines. The loadout of your craft can be customized as well. Equip the fast
column28: ship seeking concussion missiles when expecting heavy starfighter resistance. Bring slow
column29: but heavy damage dealing proton torpedoes when on a bombing run. Like any good game
column30: there's a good bit of strategy mixed in with the skill required to succeed.\n\nThe game does the movies such great justice. Seemingly every measure was taken to try to deliver the experience of piloting a starfighter just like in the movies. The little details like what systems and weapons and speeds each of the Star Wars craft should have are perfectly replicated here in the game. Concessions are not made. For instance
column32: TIE Interceptors and TIE Bombers have no hyperdrives. They need to return back to the star destroyer or space platform from which they launched at the end of the mission. They also have no shielding systems
column33: so they can be destroyed in two or three shots. Just like the movies. It's the little details that give this game so much credit with me and probably with other Star Wars fans as well. The game is even voice acted
column34: and acted surprisingly well considering it was 1994. Most of the missions take place between The Battle of Hoth and The Battle of Endor
column35: but for the super hardcore Star Wars fans
column36: there's a whole set of missions that has you serving for Grand Admiral Thrawn
column37:
from Timothy Zahn's Heir to the Empire books. There's lots of really awesome Star Wars references and homages like that throughout the game.

Summary:
KOTOR and Jedi Knight/Dark Forces come close
column38: but this is definitely the best Star Wars game ever made. Don't believe me? Check this game out. It's fun
column40: requires a good mix of skill and strategy
column41: and is very true to the movies.\n\nFor more game reviews

reviewText:
Aha! Tie FIghter, from my mis-spent youth.
Who didn't want to fly the for the Empire; no shields and just raw skill and a Transparisteel viewport between you and the void.  One of the best Star Wars games made and from when LucasArts were at their peak!

The Good, The Bad, The Ugly

The Good:
Includes the Dos Version and the Windows version !!! and now includes the Collectors edition !!!
Excellent Storyline
Indepth Mission structure with secret missions from the Emperor himself
Excellent flight model, quite easy to pick up, but so many possibilities with energy management
Fly with Darth Vader; and fly under the command of the enigmatic tactician, Admiral Thrawn.
Click play and away you go
Update:
You can have the 640x480 res with gourad shading (considered superior by some) and the wicked imuse reactive soundtrack in the new-to-steam Collectros CDRom Edition!


The Bad
Windows Version doesn't have the iMuse Soundtrack (One of the better aspects)
Graphics Highly dated!
Some minor bugs
Windows version  requires a Joystick or a Gamepad to play, if you haven't got that you are out of luck for the windows version
Dosbox version is Gouard Shaded only, no textures!
The Hardware mode doesn't work!!! (unless you go in for some exe hexing!)

The Ugly
My Eyes, My Eyes!! The graphics man!!! obviously I've spoiled myself with 1920x1080 gaming, 640x480x16 just doesn't cut the mustard (or 320x240 on Dosbox version, remember that??!!! I do!) so unless you get that nostalgia factor you'll be disappointed.

That said I still endorse and recommend this game, its a piece of gaming history, if you haven't played it, try it, you might like it if you can get past the graphics

reviewText:
I nearly peed my pants when I saw this come onto Steam.  This has to be one of the best space combat simulator sims to ever come out.  Sure, the graphics and engine are very dated now, but the story and missions are undoubtedly still great.

This game follows the story of the Empire chasing down the Rebellion after the Battle of Hoth.  Still unable to face the might of the Empire directly, the Rebels flee their no-longer-secret base and scatter, evading the Empire until they can find a new home.  As an Imperial pilot, you are hunting them down, destroying their convoys, and fighting them at every opportunity.  Muhahahaha!

The graphics are the same and the interface will take some time to get used to (it's so primitive!)  I only played a few minutes so far, but my Xbox 360 controller kinda works.  I'll have to figure out how to bind some keys to it so I don't have to keep jumping to my keyboard every few seconds.  Either that or I'll have to break down and just get a stick.  =/  Otherwise it seems to handle pretty smoothly.
voteText: 69 of 85 people (81%) found this review helpful 7 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I'm not the biggest Flight Sim fan, but I am a die hard Star Wars fan and TIE Fighter is, hands down, the BEST Flight Sim ever made. I spent so many hours in High School playing this game over and over and never getting tired of it. This game, Jedi Knight, and the KOTOR series are the best Star Wars games to date, masterpieces in their own ways, that leave you begging and coming back for more.

A few things before I review it, this does include the updated version of the game with the better textures and also the DOS classic. I prefer the remake because it immerses me a lot more than the polygon DOS version. Not to say DOS games are bad (love Dark Forces and Betrayal At Krondor) but with the updated textures, you can see you're really going after a Gold A-Wing or a freighter and the like. Also, USB controllers do work for this game. My Logitech Dual Action (Looks like a PS2 controller if you're unsure) is USB and works perfectly for this game.

Everything about this game is perfect. You get a decent plot moved through by cutscenes between battles and missions, a pre-mission briefing and debriefing with a flight officer and a servant of the Empreror himself, and great in flight orders and notifications from the flight officer and other wingmen.

The gameplay is fantastic, making you feel like you are a pilot for the Empire. You have many options for combat and defense in terms of matching speed with targets, ion cannons to disable ships, warheads for extra punch on small fighters to capital ships, scans to see what ships are carrying, even balancing weapon to shield to engine recharge rates. This flexibility gives a great element of strategy, do you need shields more or will you sacrifice them for speed and so on.

Combat is extremely fun. A-Wing pilot dogfighting is my favorite since they are fast and programmed to dodge you well. Taking down capital ships and surviving, what can I say? A great thrill watching a frigate blow up from your heavy rockets.

Ships range from the classic TIE, Bomber, Interceptor, Advanced, Defender (my personal fav), and two specialty ships, the assault gunboat for heavy combat with fighters to capital ships and a Missile Boat used to intercept warheads fired at capital ships. The combat simulator allows you to play with the different types to get a feel for them before trying them in the campaign.

Music,I hear the MIDI system on DOS is a lot better than the updated. I will admit, the music loops, but it's classic Star Wars John Williams crystal clear tracks. It is repeatitive, but hey, put on your own tracks on iTunes or turn the music off. My fav part with the music, however, is when you accomplish an objective, the Imperial March plays, making you feel like a boss for taking out some Rebel Scum.

As for downsides to the game...it's really hard for me to find any outside of two petty issues. One, it can get repeatitive. Fly and target this ship, defend this ship, take this capital ship out, etc. The story and flow and immersion make up for that. Game tasks can be repeatitive, but I know some people can get bored with that sort of thing. It's nothing to the point of boredom, however. You may feel you're doing the same thing, but the plot flow and mission flow easily make up for that. Second, I want more missions. I want to fly between episodes 3 and 4 and 5 and 6 and beyond. I wanna see new ships on both sides. Either than that, this game has no real downsides imo.

Even if you're not a Flight Sim fan, you will love this game, especially if you're a Star Wars fan. X-Wing was the start of magic, TIE Fighter took X-Wing and blew it out of the water taking X-Wing's excellent ideas and multiplying them by a thousand. This is a must own for new gamers, old gamers, and a great chance to reclaim a classic that is compatible on modern OS (I have 7, works fine. Heard issues for 10, hopefully will be fixed). Get this game, you won't be disappointed.

10 out of 10

reviewText:
TIE Fighter is one of the best Star Wars games I've ever played.  I first played it at a friend’s house, and then went home to beg my parents to buy a 386 computer so I could play it at home too (this was during the 486 era).  I spent 100's of hours fighting for the empire in this game, and I don't regret a single moment of it!  Granted, the graphics are a bit dated by today's standards, but the gameplay is still unparalleled!

When this showed up on steam I wanted to buy it, but with reports of errors, and a missing 1995 Collector's CD-ROM (IMHO the best edition), I couldn't justify the purchase. But just today they reported fixing the problems, and adding the Collector's CD-ROM edition, so I purchased it to try it out.

Now I'm happy to report that the 1995 Collector's CD-ROM edition works exactly as a fan would expect on windows 10!  The 1994 floppy disk version works perfectly too! But the 1998 'Special Edition' version had some issues.  It required me to download some direct draw files to play in 3D mode, and add a startup switch to hide the mouse cursor, which is all covered by 'Solution 1 - XWA Wrapper' in this community post.  It was a small hastle, and still crashes when a song finishes every once in a while, but not bad when you take into account the fact that this game is over 20 years old.  As an added bonus for doing this, the 'Special Edition' version can then be played in stretched widescreen with a very simple config edit to the above XWA Wrapper solution!

Steam controller owners have access to a community binding that sets the controller up so you won't ever have to use the keyboard for any in-flight function!

10/10 + 1 point for widescreen = 11/10

reviewText: Just wanted to put a confirmation that this is working on windows 7 64-bit with no issues and picked up and auto-configured my joystick without me even having to do anything.\n\nThis is one of the greatest experiences any star wars game out there has to offer and gives a fantastic look at the Imperial side of the war. If you missed it when it came out in the 90's this is a great chance to try it out, and for all my fellow TIE veterans: It's back just like you remember it.

reviewText:
It pains me to say this but Tie-Fighter is virtually unplayable on any modern system.  I guess if you want to use the work arounds that even allow the game to run on any modern system it can be fine but what's the point.  I cant imagine using the included DOS version with no voice.  The included 98 version will 100% refuse to run on anything from Windows 7 to Windows 10 unless you modify the game yourself with assorted DLL files.  However doing this will cause multiple graphic problems, kill the in game music and cause mouse duplication in some cases - well it did in mine.

Just by looking in the discussion forum and in the threads, its painful to see how little (read: none) support is given from the people who are actually selling the game and taking your hard earned money.  Ultimately I cannot recommend this on a purely technical level - I cant imagine veterans wanting to have the nostalgia ruined by this technical mess and I cannot fathom anyone new to the series to even dare try this for the first time.

To end, this is also a statement on Steams quality control - all games really should be tested on basic operating systems and if you try to sell a game from 1994/1998 and it doesnt run, or even guarenteed to run, on a modern system of anything in the last 5 years please explicitly say this in the memos.  I am thankful for Steam refunds, I'm sad that the chance was not worth it - I will instead be happy with the memory of the hundreds of hours I put into this game and series instead.

reviewText:
Doesn't include the collector's edition of the game, which is the one I prefer.

The 1998 version of the game has decent graphics, but the audio is terrible and cuts out all the time, and it always crashes when using the 3D hardware option, so be aware of that. This version also just uses standard Star Wars music all the time, which doesn't really fit with what you're doing in most cases. I can't stop getting my desktop mouse cursor from rendering in the upper left corner of the game, and often mouse input will just get messed up until I alt-tab out. This version also requires a joystick, and there's no way to change the deadzone, so controllers are sort of terrible to play with.

The DOS version works fine, but it's really low res and doesn't have the voice acting, hence the desire from the community for the collector's CD version of the game. It kind of sucks that they didn't include the best iteration of the DOS version. For now this is a pass until they add the collector's CD version, if only so I don't have to listen to the crappy audio cutting out and the weird processing they put over voices. I'm kind of disappointed.

reviewText: This is an absolutely amazing game, it got me to buy a flightstick and was worth the 10 minutes of troubleshooting it takes to get it working. You feel truly vunlarable and outclassed by the enemy and the only way to defeat them is outplay them. Each ship feels completely different from the last, and it includes a variety of ships from the EU such as the Tie Defender. The fun of this game comes from failing until you realize what the true objective is and the satisfaction you feel when you perfectly execute a mission and all its bonus objectives. Now with newer .dlls available the music works.\n\nEdit: Now you can play what most people consider the best version the 1995 Collector's CD. I tried it and like it, still a bit buggy and I dislike how it doesn't recognize the throttle.

reviewText: Such a great classic. I have fond memories as a child playing, both this game and X-Wing, dogfighting, chasing ships, scanning freighters, and carrying out secret missions for the Republic/Empire. At first I was disdained that Steam did not include the vastly superior Collector's CD versions like GOG did. But as of May 3, 2016 they are now included! So I can't recommend them enough to you and anybody that likes space simulators as this is one of the best there is! Every version is compatible with gamepads (though with the DOS versions it doesn't seem like you can really remap controls so you need to play in conjunction with a keyboard, but the controller is intuitive enough).\n\nPlease play both this and X-Wing. These are two of the best LucasArts games (and 90s games in general) that you will find. You'll have a blast! Thank you, Disney, for finally including the Collector's CD editions! (even though it took about a year!)

reviewText: TIE Fighter is one of my favorite childhood games, so I was pumped to see it released on Steam.  Unfortunately, there are some issues that keep me from recommending this verison of the game.  The Special Edition has a software-enforced dead zone, so my Logitech Extreme 3D joystick is absolutely incapable of making fine adjustments.  The game is unplayable as a result.  The Classic Edition doesn't have this problem, if you can deal with the chunky DOS graphics.\n\nI'm left disappointed, because TIE Fighter is truly a great game.  Maybe if Steam offered the 1995 version like GOG does, I could have the best of both worlds.

reviewText: Who would've thought one of the best Star Wars games, and even one of the best PC games ever, would have you playing as the bad guys? TIE Fighter includes 13 campaigns where you can fly 7 different fighters and bombers (though you don't get to choose which one). Advance through the ranks, earn medals, and enter the Secret Order of the Emperor. This game is certainly a marked improvement over the original X-Wing. It's easier, has more spacecraft in its library to use, the targeting display features a 3D model, among other things. If you've wanted to fight for the Empire, this is the game to do it.

reviewText:
The granddaddy of all games that teaches you it is good to be the bad guy! I was amazed to see this for sale on Steam, has to be because of the May 4th special, May the 4th be with you" coming up. It took me all of ten seconds to snatch it into my cart.

I was so excited once I got the game running I jumped right into the combat simulator and crashed into the cargo container about five seconds later. After a restart which because it is an old game takes about ten seconds I ran out cleared all primary and secondary and half the bonus objectives.

The game has also withstood the test of time. You remember how you thought games were cool twenty years ago then tried them again and went wow that game is bad now. I cna honestly say this game has taken that test and pass with flying colors.

I had a couple game crashes at first
date: which honestly you have to expect that taking an old DOS game and running it on a "supercomputer" compared to what it was designed to run on. Restarted the game in the 98 mode and it ran fine.\n\nEven with the out of date graphics you are going to get WAY more entertainment for your $9 than you will probably get out of a $30-50 dollar game these days. They just do not make games like this anymore."

reviewText:
Increase forward fire power! Too late! *Kabloom!*

Pros:
+Play as The Galactic Empire! Fly standard Tie Fighters, Tie Interceptors, Defenders, and other imperial fighter/shuttle crafts.
+Unlock Cutscenes that tell a uniques Expanded Universe Story featuring: your pilot (you), Admiral Thrawn (you see him get promoted!), The Emperor, Darth Vader, and many other imperials
+Runs good on Windows 7 and PC's with integrated graphics
+Enjoy customizable controls or use the default
+Does work with controllers/joystick or mouse and keyboard
+Includs plenty of bonus training missions to help ease you into the flight experience
+Has an easy setting lol

Con:
-Graphics are dated (but they are smooth enough to know what everything is)
-Controls are difficult with mousepad and keyboard (but a normal mouse & keyboard can help)
-The long wait until the mod community comes out with an HD update for all these classic Star Wars 90's flight simulators (All the X-Wing & Tie Fighter games especially)
-Default controls are better suited for lefties (I am a right handed and it does not bother me--I adapt.
But I can imagine it bothering some people)

9.5/10 I throughly enjoy this game, as both a Star Wars and flight simulator fan. If you can figure out your best control technique, go with a normal mouse/keyboard, unless you have a joystick/controller that is compatible. The graphics are 90's graphics, but are very smooth and crisp for that era of gaming. That being said, modern gamers may want to check ModDB.com for modders working on these Classic Star Wars 90's Flight Sims. (X-Wing Alliance is currently the only one listed with an HD mod in the works. Looks promising. Maybe something can happen like how people updated Half-Life 1 with a HD update via Black Mesa.)

reviewText:
Great Classic and Worth Buying

I use to play this all the time when i was a kid. Played it on DOS, then got it on windows. Great game back in those days. I bought this back in december when steam had those major specials going on and it was worth it. At first it didnt come with all 3 versions of the game but since may 4th of 2016, they included the CD-ROM DOS Version as well making it total to 3 versions of the game. The X-Wing game had the same update as well. I know Good Old Games site had all 3 versions at first but when i saw this on steam for a very good price along with other games included on a special price, couldnt resist.

Does this game run on 64 bit windows? Yes it does. Ran it on Windows 8.1 64-bit and worked well without a hitch.

Having it on steam does save me all the trouble from having to rely on 3rd party programs that could manually install the game and run them on a 64 bit since the CD's Installers were not able to run on 64-bit systems.

reviewText:
Fixes everything wrong with the first X Wing game and improves on it even more!

First of all, I'll talk about the different versions. Many people claim that the collector's edition is the best version of this game, and chose to not recommend this game because it doesn't come with that version. Well, your mileage may very, but I found I preferred the special edition version.

Other than that, my favorite thing about this game is that it gives you the ability to adjust the difficulty so you don't get too frustrated. Unlike the previous X Wing game, you have difficulty settings and you can turn on cheats without losing the ability to progress in the story. This makes this game MUCH more playable and fun - and it still gives you some incentive to play with the harder settings by penalizing your score if you use cheats or play on easier difficulty settings.

Overall, though, it's really immersive in the same way (though not QUITE as spectacular) as Republic Commando. There's voice acting in missions which makes it easier to keep track of what is going on and adds to the feeling that you're actually there.

I don't know what it's like if you don't have a joystick, though, so I can't comment on that.

reviewText:
In many ways this was the game that got me into games.  I love this game and it isn't just nostalgia: on replay I find it not only holds up but it excels in an oversaturated market.

Perfectly immersive.  Craft feel fundamentally different as you fly them.  Enemy pilots exhibit ranges of skill and courage.  Missions are varied, with great in-universe briefings to set the scene.  The main plot is an exercise in show-don't-tell which casts the player as a peacekeeper on the side of order in a galaxy torn apart by piracy.  A secretive figure brings secondary mission objectives which  reveal subplots and the favour of the Emperor himself to those who dig a little deeper.

It's hard, but (unlike its predecessor X-Wing) it rarely feels unfair.  I find myself leaping back into missions I've failed to give 'em another go.

This Steam version is the definitive version of the game, including the two expansions, touched-up (comparatively) hi-rez models, and the fully voiced audio track of the Special Edition.  If you bought it on GoG, buy it again here.

It might be hard to get into it if you weren't a fan of Star Wars' space battles, but - to me at least - it's as close as you can get to a perfect game.

reviewText:
Tie Fighter is one of the greatest flight-sims ever released!
And you can now get both the original '94 DOS version AND the '98 Windows version with updated visuals and voiceovers in one package right here on Steam! Seems great? Well, there is a catch.
Y'see, the '98 release lacks the dynamic music technology of the '94 release.
There was in fact a version released in '95 that featured the best of both worlds
with the dynamic music of the '94 release and the voicework of the '98 release.
That version was recently added to GOG.com after complaints about its absence.
And yet, it is nowhere to be found on Steam.
To be clear, I DO recommend this game, it's just not the ideal version to get right now.

reviewText:
This is a brilliant game- its not as hard as some make it out to be but th combat is very fun and thankfully different ship classes do not much alte the flying at all. Be aware that you need a console control pad for this game with about 11 buttons and also note that it takes a good 10-15 miutes to set up the controls as there are over 100, most of which you dont need.


Good points-

Brilliant dogfighting
Very clear to understand once you are used to it
Full simulation - almost 30 commands for squads for example but only 5 are needed
Friendly wingmen are utterly deadly to other ships when directed to attack something
Just like in real Star Wars, Tie fighters only take 2 shots to kill, but X/Y-wings are more durable
Actually pretty good graphics on special edition.
Feels like you are piloting a tie fighter

Cons-

Not easy to understand at first
Difficulty is abit punishing and there are no checkpoints mid-mission

reviewText: The biggest problems with this game lie in controlling it.  You're gonna need a joystick.  An XBox controller will work, but remapping the controls is confusing, and some controls are not remappable. reviewText:
I've wanted this to be on Steam for a long time now since my old CD version from the 90s doesn't work on a modern computer.  And now finally it is.

It's just as I remembered it.  Slaughter rebel scum, pirates and traitors alike as you do what most games don't allow you to: fight for the Empire.  It's the game that endeared my to the Galactic Empire in the first place, the game that introduced me to the amazing expanded universe character Admiral Thrawn.

Fly in numerous Imperial fighters not limited to just the classic TIEs, but also other craft like the Gun Boat, Missile Boat and the epic TIE Defender.  Participate in dogfights and assault enemy capital ships.  All in all a wonderful experience then, and it will be now as well.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I'm recommending this with caveats.

I loved this when it was new. It mostly came down to the Star Wars games or the Wing Commander series if you wanted a first person space combat sim... and flying a Tie Figher (or an X-Wing, depending on game) was far too much of a drawcard not to give it a go.

Unfortunately, it really has dated very badly. It can still be a lot of fun, but the clumsy interface and horrible resolution leaves a lot to be desired in this day and age.  The missions are heavily scripted, but challenging. You can be blown up almost right at the end of a very long mission, and will need to start again from scratch.  At first this is fine, but maybe I've been spoiled by the quick-save generation of games... but having to repeat the same scripted missions over and over really started to feel like a grind.

In short - it's a great game that hasn't aged well. If you love the early Star Wars universe and don't mind a bit of antiquation, then this could well be the game for you.  If you're wanting to re-live the space combat sim of your youth, however... have a long hard think about how rose-tinted your nostalgia glasses are before you buy it.

reviewText:

Update: with a little work I was able to get the game working perfectly & have updated this review accordingly.

If you get black screen on open:
1: browse local files, got to Remastered"
date: delete ddraw.dll and winmm.dll\nat this stage the game should be working. If you have distorted colours\n2: download http://bitpatch.com/ddwrapper.html
recommended: this fakes the original ddraw.dll and alows you to fix some translation bugs. put the new ddraw.dll and aqrit.cfg in the Remasterd folder\n3: open aqrit in notepad and set ColorFix to 1\n4: Enjoy TIE Fighter"

reviewText:
EDIT 5: Only one that matters -- rest of post is irrelevant now.  As of 5/3/2016, the 1 year exlusive deal GoG had on CD Collector's edition is over with.  Patched to include this on steam.  Now this release has parity with the GoG version and is a big thumbs up.




EDIT2: This is greatest game for PC ever, don't be confused.  However, the thumbs down is for this particular Steam version.  Note, though, that despite its failure to include the Collector's CD, it is possible to MOD that stuff in.  This will remain a thumbs down to inform would-be buyers of the deficiency, however.


Recommend purchasing the version on GOG and not this one.

This does not currently include the Collector's Edition CD version, commonly regarded as the best version of this game.

This one gives you an option between launching the Classic version (1994 DOS) and the Remastered (1998 Windows).

The Classic lacks the rather atmosphere defining voice files for the briefings and the graphics upgrades that is included in the Collector's Edition CD.

The Remastered kills the ambiance by lacking the dynamic music system and old school MIDIs and other penchants of the DOS/Collector's Edition.

Meanwhile the Collector's Edition CD version is included seemingly exclusively in the GOG version (announced today, 4/28/2015).

EDIT: Recommend purchase on GOG IF GOG's advertising claim that it has the Collector's CD is true... you'll have to see GOG's website and its user comments about that one.
EDIT3: Folks are saying it is true. Users may just have to refresh account to get it on their list.

EDIT4: I had emailed Disney support regarding the Collector's CD absence inquiring about its inclusion in the future.  I received a somewhat cheeky response: we are not sure what kind of content could be coming out for this game in the future. It's new to steam
Brings back so many good memories, but I could do without the bugs and crashes it was plagued with back in the 90's. Thanks Disney, for putting out a cheap re-pack of a Star Wars classic.

reviewText:
Please make this game compatible. It was one of the best Star Wars games of all time. It's frustrating to spend money on a product that doesn't work. I see that Galactic Battlegrounds is fixed. Please put the time and effort into making this classic run again.

In it's current state I can't recommend this game.

Edit May 18, 2016: It works now. Sunk 25 hours of gameplay into it and it's as fun as I remembered.
